author: A_Brickset_user
title: Life in Lego?
review: This was my second set in the Life on Mars theme, and initially, I was quite impressed. The cool Martian minifig is a must have; it is too bad there is only one included with this set. As for the Red Planet Protector itself, there is some play value in the sense that you can transform it by snapping off the guns and replacing them with the leg thrusters to make a flying vehicle. However, it is really only good for posing, as it lacks knees and practically any decent joint structure. The parts are very nice though, and comein good colors like blue and dark grey. Several custom pieces, like the big gun and cockpit, are great for Space MOCs. Overall, this set suffers in the fact it was released at a dark time for Lego. Bionicle had not quite started yet and Star Wars was a bittersweet victory. Though Life on Mars did not worsen the imbalance, it certaintly did not help it. The set's crudness might allow it to be easily overlooked compared to mech sets like the new Titan XP, but it is a nice-looking set, for display or MOCing uses. Take your pick.

author: couchz
title: Red Planet Protector Review
review:
Life on Mars is one of those themes that up until recently seems to be forgotten about such as Roborider, Znap, and Time Cruisers. 

 

Building process 

The build is relatively simple, although it has some of that 90's early 2000's simplicity. Multiple parts of a set are held together with Technic pins letting you mix and match the parts. The base build is a Mech in the back of the instruction booklet; it suggests you could turn it into a spaceship instead.

 

Parts 

As previously mentioned, the parts are relatively basic. There are some specific-use parts such as the  2x4x5 jet engines or the hoses with a stud on one end. It also has 2 or 3 pieces, expertly printed to look like electronics. The color scheme of the bricks is dark gray and sand blue.  It works well with a neon orange touch. 

 

Playability 

If I had had this set when I was 10, I would have played with it every day.  Even though I'm older, I can see the playability and the appeal of this set. The minifigure of the set is a weird blend of battle droid torso and humanoid features. It has seemingly come to a middle ground of not being as robotic looking but not quite human, which works for me. The figure has a limited range of articulation because it uses the same design as a battle droid. The Mech legs can move side to side, and up and down. The cockpit is connected by a Technic pin and can be popped off to make it fly around.


 

Ending  thoughts 

Overall I would give the set a 7 out of 10. There are some small problems that I think could be fixed by just adding a piece or two. If you want to buy this set, the average price today used is about $30. For a set that is 21 years old, this has withheld the test of time.

author: Stud_Sensei
title: Look mom, no hands!
review:
Unlike the mech lineups today like those found in the Marvel sets, each of the mechs found in the LoM range are drastically distinct. Judging by eBay listings at the time of writing, this clearly didn't work out well for 7313 - Red Planet Protector, which boasts notably fewer (and pricier) listings than its more conventional stablemate, 7314 - Recon Mech RP. We'll see whether it rightfully deserves second-billing.

Unlike 7314, 7313 deviates from the mechanised norm and forgoes any arms, for two large fixed scanners / blasters on the upper torso, and a pair of hip-thrusters connected below. This reduces the range of poses available to the model drastically, but seems to be in order to incorporate its different design intent, as we'll see. 7313 also stands taller than 7314, further differentiating their silhouettes, and lacks its more exciting parts, such as the container, claw or any accessories for the 'fig, which would've bumped up its playability some. We do still get a nice sprinkle of small printed pieces, though, which is nice.

First, the figure. The sole minifigure included in this, Centauri, makes their only appearance outside a polybag in this set, and is about as decent as the LoM martians came, with a nicely printed respirator(?) head design and a blue body to match their mech. The limited articulation is disappointing, but this is nothing new for these 'droid' style figures which LEGO has yet to improve in over 20 years of production, so the focus on compatible equipment and machinery throughout the range somewhat makes up for it.

Those upper torso armaments are where the frustrations start with this set. Instead of being fixed in place, or articulated, these are instead attached via a loose pin connection and held horizontal by a hinged piece. So, instead of the freedom to pose them, we get two choices: straight-forward, or dangling uselessly. Why couldn't these have given friction pins, at the very least? Why this non-choice, where one pose just looks flatly odd? This is repeated with the hip thrusters as well - they look great, incorporating the brilliant engine piece common to the range, and are admittedly more poseable, able to use their own weight to hold themselves in place at a range of angles - but again, it begs the questions of why not just use friction pins in their place?

The hint lies in one of the tags of this set on Brickset - 'converts'. Indeed, these quirks seem to be in order to sell the second form of 7313 where, by removing its bottom half and plugging half of a leg into its back, it becomes some sort of clumsy flying machine (a UFO?). The free moving thrusters also seem to suggest that it can be used as a sort of VTOL, with each of the four thrusters pivoting to aim downwards while keeping the model in mech form. Unfortunately, neither of these forms are very well realised - the flying form is far too dumpy to feel like more than an afterthought, and looks like a similar (but worse) form of 7311 - Red Planet Cruiser. And the model does not convince as a VTOL, because it still looks too much of a mech while doing it. Despite compromising its design as a mech, these design choices fail to make the model convince as a flying machine either. That's not to say it's a bad idea - a convertible flying mech sounds great! - but I wish they had gone further, perhaps adding more thrusters with better articulation, really making these features clear. 

So there's a great core concept underpinning 7313. Unfortunately, because of some truly bizarre design decisions, this concept ends up only vaguely gestured at, with neither of its two suggested forms being particularly well-executed and resulting in a confused, middling model. Still, despite these shortcomings, it inherits the LoM range's consistently excellent visual design and meshes well with the rest of the range, meaning it just about crosses the line into a recommendation.
